Church and state are officially separate in Russia, but many see the Orthodox Church as the official religion in all but name.
In the 1990s, the state gave the church tax breaks to trade in alcohol and tobacco, enabling it to become a lucrative business.

But while more than two-thirds of Russians say they're Orthodox believers, only around 10 percent actually attend services regularly.
Conservative voices in the church, like Deacon Andrei Kuraev, blame the low level of attendance on the church's attempts to cultivate political influence with the Kremlin.

But you segued into this area of sexuality.
And I wondered if you can tell us about that evolution and why you are now focusing on this area.
Sure.
I'd be happy to.

The story goes back to around 1984, a long time ago, when children's television was deregulated and it became possible to market toys with TV shows, whole lines of toys and increasingly other products.

And when that happened, I started hearing concerns from teachers and parents about the kinds of struggles they were having with war play and kid boys - especially boys involved with aggressive and violent scenes in their play that they hadn't been seeing before.
And since I'm very interested in children's play and, as well, their gender development, I wanted to understand what was going on.
And what I found was that after de-regulation in '84, almost all of the most popular shows children were watching were linked to lines of toys.
And almost all of the best-selling toys had TV shows.
And many of them were violent, like Masters of the Universe.
Some of your listeners will remember quite well, I'm sure, He Man.
And we had Transformers and GI Joe.
And boys got more and more involved in violence.

And teachers started talking about how there were more gender divisions in the play that they were seeing in young children in classrooms, that children - when boys and girls used to play together, more and more now they would segregating themselves.
So, right at that point, I started looking at girls, too.
And what we found was that girls were much more involved in things like Care Bears and My Little Pony, which had become the popular TV shows with whole lines of toys and other products.
And girls were being shown that they should be sweet and they should be nice.
And there was a great kind of divide that had begun to happen again.
I had been in the field when the women's movement started and we talked about how to help boys and girls develop the biggest range of potentials as possible.
And that didn't mean they'd be exactly the same, but they all had more, as many possible potentials developed.
And what we were seeing was boys and girls being narrowed in their play into fewer and fewer themes.
Girls were being pretty, sweet and nice, and boys were being tough and macho and rugged individuals.
And how does that translate into this whole area of sexualization of kids and what they're watching in the media?
Right.
Well, good question.
Because what's happened ever since that time that I was describing is that the gender divisions have increased, things have gotten more violent for boys.
And the girl scene has gotten more and more focusing on appearance, still, and being sexy folded into the appearance.
So that from a very young age, girls are learning that the way they look, what they wear, what they buy, affects who they are, how they should feel about themselves and their whole self-image.
And it also is how they start judging other people.
And that for young children is the beginning of thinking about their bodies and how they feel about their bodies and how their bodies work.

It doesn't start out at three, four, five, six and seven, with children specifically focusing on sex.
It's much more focused on relationships and affection, and how - but more and more the culture as it is now, their bodies, how they look.
And what's getting folded in now, in terms of sexiness, is connected more to older children and teenagers.
